title: Throughout this work I use ‘‘elite’’ as a social and economic term and ‘‘aristocracy’’ as a political term. The Roman elite was the highest social and economic rank of Roman citizens, equivalent to those who possessed the equestrian census and were members of ‘‘the moneyed class’

The Roman aristocracy, without exception, were those Romans who held curule office and, therefore, would normally become members of the senate. The aristocracy was the political subset of the elite. See Hopkins and Burton, ‘‘Political Succession in the Late Republic (249–50 B.C.),’

title: who suggested the citizen cavalry gradually disappeared without any sudden reform.
